title: Right-to-die, climate change, pot and more: Here are 10 bills that will change life – and death – in California
text:
Gov. Jerry Brown signed a flurry of bills during the past week addressing matters as cosmic as assisted suicide and as trivial as electric skateboards.
On Saturday and Sunday alone, just before the deadline, Brown greenlighted 85 separate pieces of legislation.
In case you missed it, here are some of the more notable bills that now bear his signature and soon will reshape life in California in large and small ways:
MOTOR VOTER 
The bill: Assembly Bill 1461
The sponsors: Assembly members Lorena Gonzalez, D-San Diego; Luis Alejo, D-Watsonville; Kevin McCarty, D-Sacramento
The mission: Boost voter registration and turnout by automatically registering people to vote when they obtain or renew driver’s licenses.
The impact on you: It will make it easier to register to vote. If you drive a car, you’ll be registered. Don’t want to vote? You will still be able to opt out. But that’s one more trip to the DMV.
RIGHT TO DIE 
The bill: ABX2-15
The sponsor: Assemblywoman Susan Talamantes Eggman, D-Stockton
The mission: Extend to Californians the right to end their lives early. California joins Oregon, Washington, Montana and Vermont.
The impact on you: If you or a loved one are facing just six months to live, it will allow you to seek a prescription of life-ending drugs from your doctor.
CLIMATE CHANGE 
The bill: Senate Bill 350
The sponsor: Senate President pro Tempore Kevin de León, D-Los Angeles
The mission: Ramp up California’s efforts to slow climate change.
The impact on you: It mandates that half of California’s electricity come from green sources such as solar and wind power by 2030.
You’ll see more electric vehicles on the roads, and existing buildings, including homes, will need to become twice as energy efficient.
DAY CARE WORKERS 
The bill: SB792
The sponsor: Sen. Tony Mendoza, D-Artesia
The mission: Require day care workers and volunteers to be vaccinated against influenza, pertussis and measles.
The impact on you: It could reduce the chance your children will get sick – because it could reduce their caretakers’ chances of getting sick.
POLITICAL ADS 
The bill: AB990
The sponsor: Assemblywoman Susan A. Bonilla, D-Concord
The mission: Increase transparency in political advertisements by requiring disclosure statements to be placed in bold boxes with large type.
The impact on you: It’ll likely make it easier for you to know who is backing a candidate or issue on the ballot. It will make the information easier to read, anyway.
SPORTS NICKNAMES 
The bill: AB30
The sponsor: Assemblyman Luis Alejo, D-Watsonville
The mission: Bar the use of the term “Redskins” as a mascot for California public schools and their sports teams.
The impact on you: For now, just four high schools in central and Northern California will have to change their mascots. But it could kickstart momentum to change the names of other schools closer to home that are regarded by some groups as offensive.
VAPING SALES 
The bill: AB216
The sponsor: Assemblywoman Cristina Garcia, D-Bell Gardens
The mission: Protect children from e-cigarettes, which some recent studies indicate can be a gateway to real cigarettes.
The impact on you: Persons under age 18 won’t be able to buy vaping products that do not have nicotine.
MEDICAL MARIJUANA 
The bills: AB243, AB266, SB643
The sponsors: Assemblyman Jim Wood, D-Healdsburg; Assemblyman Rob Bonta, D-Alameda; Sen. Mike McGuire, D-Healdsburg
The mission: Provide a framework for regulating the production, distribution and sale of medical marijuana.
The impact on you: This patchwork of pot laws aims to stitch together a cohesive statewide system for providing marijuana to Californians for medicinal purposes and will replace scores of local ordinances.
CHEWING TOBACCO 
The bill: AB768
The sponsor: Assemblyman Tony Thurmond, D-Richmond
The mission: Bar professional baseball players from chewing tobacco while playing games in California stadiums.
The impact on you: The law aims to prevent chaw-chomping baseball players from having a negative “role-model effect” on California youths. So your kids might not grow up longing to plop a viscous wad in their cheeks, just because some all-star slugger does.
ELECTRIC SKATEBOARDS 
The bill: SB604
The sponsor: Assemblywoman Kristin M. Olsen, R-Modesto
The mission: Legalize electric skateboards and regulate their use.
The impact on you: Allows electric skateboards on streets or trails, but requires operators to wear helmets and to be at least 16 years old – and it bars them from riding while under the influence of alcohol or drugs.
Could hoverboards be next, Marty?
Contact the writer: 951-368-9699 or ddowney@pe.com
